question_content.text: What is React?

answer_content.text: A JavaScript library for building user interfaces.
A programming language developed by Facebook.
A database management system.
A server-side scripting language.

question_content.text: Does React use HTML?

answer_content.text: Yes, it uses JSX, which is similar to HTML.
No, it uses XML exclusively.
Yes, it uses HTML directly.
No, it uses a custom markup language.

question_content.text: When was React first released?

answer_content.text: March 2013.
June 2015.
January 2010.
December 2017.

question_content.text: What are two significant drawbacks of React?

answer_content.text: Integrating React with the MVC framework like Rails requires complex configuration.
React has no support for third-party libraries.
React is not compatible with modern browsers.
React is primarily designed for server-side scripting.

question_content.text: State the difference between Real DOM and Virtual DOM.

answer_content.text: Real DOM updates slowly; Virtual DOM updates faster.
Real DOM allows direct updates from HTML; Virtual DOM cannot be used to update HTML directly.
Real DOM consumes less memory; Virtual DOM wastes too much memory.
Real DOM is used exclusively in React; Virtual DOM is used in other JavaScript libraries.

question_content.text: What is Flux Concept in React?

answer_content.text: A new kind of architecture that complements React and the concept of Unidirectional Data Flow.
A design pattern for creating server-side rendering in React applications.
A built_in React library for managing global state.
A tool for optimizing React performance.

question_content.text: Define the term Redux in React.

answer_content.text: A state container for JavaScript applications used for state management.
A library for handling asynchronous actions in React.
A router library for navigation in React applications.
A styling framework for React components.

question_content.text: What is the 'Store' feature in Redux?

answer_content.text: Allows saving the application's entire state in one place.
A container for storing React components.
A feature for handling server-side rendering in Redux.
A tool for optimizing React performance.

question_content.text: What is an action in Redux?

answer_content.text: A function that returns an action object.
A built_in React component for handling user input.
A type of CSS animation used in React applications.
A feature for handling asynchronous actions in Redux.

question_content.text: Name the important features of React.

answer_content.text: Allows you to use 3rd party libraries.
Designed for slow development processes.
Not supported by Facebook.
Does not support code stability.

question_content.text: What is the purpose of the React createContext function?

answer_content.text: To create a context for sharing values like themes among components.
To define a new React component.
To handle asynchronous actions in React applications.
To create a new React class.

question_content.text: What are the four different phases in the lifecycle of a React component?

answer_content.text: Initialization, Mounting, Updating, and Unmounting.
Configuration, Rendering, State, and Event Handling.
Setup, Execution, Refresh, and Cleanup.
Preparation, Deployment, Maintenance, and Decommissioning.

question_content.text: What are the limitations of React?

answer_content.text: React is not a full-blown framework, and it might be difficult for beginners to understand.
React is limited to server-side rendering only.
React components do not support inline templating.
React does not provide any form of state management.

question_content.text: Explain the difference between Shadow DOM and Virtual DOM.

answer_content.text: Shadow DOM is for scoping variables and CSS in web components, while Virtual DOM is a concept implemented by libraries in JavaScript.
Shadow DOM and Virtual DOM are two terms referring to the same concept in React.
Shadow DOM is used exclusively in React, and Virtual DOM is used in other JavaScript libraries.
Virtual DOM is for scoping variables and CSS in web components, while Shadow DOM is a concept implemented by libraries in JavaScript.

question_content.text: What is the purpose of the ReactTestUtils package?

answer_content.text: To perform actions against a simulated DOM for the purpose of unit testing.
To handle asynchronous actions in React applications.
To create a new React component.
To optimize the performance of React components.

question_content.text: What are the core principles of Redux?

answer_content.text: Single source of truth, State is read-only, Changes are made with pure functions.
Global state, Direct state modification, State transformations with impure functions.
Multiple sources of truth, Mutable state, Changes are made with impure functions.
Single source of truth, State is write-only, Changes are made with pure functions.

question_content.text: How can you access the Redux store outside a component?

answer_content.text: Export the store from the module where it is created with createStore().
Use the window object to access the global Redux store.
Call a special function provided by React called getReduxStore().
Accessing the Redux store outside a component is not possible.

question_content.text: Explain the yield catchphrase in JavaScript.

answer_content.text: The yield catchphrase is used to delay and resume a generator function, which is known as the yield keyword.
The yield catchphrase is a syntax error in JavaScript.
The yield catchphrase is used to declare variables in JavaScript.
The yield catchphrase is only applicable to asynchronous functions.

question_content.text: What is the difference between a React component and a container in React Redux?

answer_content.text: A component is for the presentational part of an application, while a container is connected to a Redux store.
A component is only used for state management, while a container is used for rendering UI elements.
A container is a synonym for a React component in React Redux.
A component and a container are terms used interchangeably in React.

question_content.text: What is the concept of Lifting State Up in React?

answer_content.text: It involves moving shared state data to the closest common ancestor when multiple components need to share the same changing data.
It refers to moving state data from parent components to child components for better performance.
It involves using the setState function to lift state data to the top level of the component tree.
It is a concept used only in class components and not in functional components.
